content.description:
“People of France! . . .The French Revolution was nothing but a precursor of another revolution, one that will be bigger, more solemn, and which will be the last. . . . What do we need besides equality of rights? We need not only that equality of rights written into the Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen; . . . We reach for something more sublime and more just: the common good or the community of goods! No more individual property in land: the land belongs to no one. . . . We declare that we can no longer put up with the fact that the great majority work and sweat for the smallest of minorities. . . . Disappear at last, revolting distinctions between rich and poor, great and small, masters and servants, rulers and ruled.
Let there no longer be any difference between people other than that of age and sex. . . . Let the supporters of justice and happiness organize in the voice of equality. . . . The Constitutions of 1791 and 1795 tightened your chains instead of breaking them. That of 1793 was a great step towards true equality, and we had never before approached it so closely. But it did not yet touch the goal, nor reach common happiness, which it nevertheless solemnly consecrated as its great principle.
PEOPLE OF FRANCE, Open your eyes and your hearts to the fullness of happiness: recognize and proclaim with us the REPUBLIC OF EQUALS.”
Sylvain Maréchal, member of the Conspiracy of the Equals, “Manifesto of the Equals,” 1796
content.question: Based on the passage, which of the following Jacobin policies best explains Maréchal’s favorable view of the Constitution of 1793?

choices.label: The imposition of the Reign of Terror
The fixing of prices and wages
The pursuit of the war against the monarchies of Europe

content.answer: The fixing of prices and wages
